data: Rectangular marble plaque, somewhat uneven along the upper edge. Borken in two down the middle, but rejoined. Slight chipping to the lower edge.

Horizontal guidelines between lines, but almost no interlineation. The text maintains left and right margins (with guideline indicating an outer right margin), with words broken across lines or abbreviated to maintain the margins. Interpuncts mark the ends of lines 2 and 3.
Tall narrow letters with pronounced serifs and curved horizontal feet to vertical strokes.
Found in area of Piazza Stesicoro (area of a Roman necropolis), Catania

I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; courtesy  Museo Archeologico Regionale Antonino Salinas; photo J.Prag 23.05.22
Partially reopened following extensive restoration work. Comprehensive collection of archaeological material, predominantly from the West of the island, with an important Etruscan collection.
Centre of Palermo, Piazza Olivella 24, 90100 - Palermo
Inscriptiones Bruttiorum Lucaniae Campaniae Siciliae Sardiniae Latinae. Pars posterior. Inscriptiones Siciliae et Sardiniae

T. Mommsen, Inscriptiones Bruttiorum Lucaniae Campaniae Siciliae Sardiniae Latinae. Pars posterior. Inscriptiones Siciliae et Sardiniae, Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum, consilio et auctoritate Academiae Litterarum Regiae Borussicae editum, 10.2 (Berlin: G. Reimer, 1883)
Iscrizioni latine lapidarie del Museo di Palermo
Livia Bivona, Iscrizioni latine lapidarie del Museo di Palermo, Sikelia 5 (Palermo: Flaccovio, 1970)
Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia
Giacomo Manganaro, «Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia», Epigraphica 51 (1989): 161–96
Robert Crellin added ids and lemmatizations
Manganaro, 1989, Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia

2uitas · vix(it) · an(nis) · II ·
3Tyche · et · Herm(es) · fe(cerunt) ·

Dis manibus Culucuitas vixit annis II Tyche et Hermes fecerunt

1DIS·MAN·CULUC
2UITAS·VIX·AN·II·
3TYCHE·ET·HERM·FE·

DISMANIBUSCULUCUITASVIXITANNISIITYCHEETHERMESFECERUNT

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text controlled against photograph ;
  • line.3: Mommsen (after Alessi): IYCHE·FHER·M·FE; Ferrua: Tyche et Herm(es) fec(erunt); Bivona: Tyche et Her(mes) fe(cerunt); Manganaro: Tyche et Herm̂a fec(erunt).

English translation

Jonathan Prag

To the shades of the underworld. Culucuitas lived for 2 years. Tyche and Hermes made this.

commentary

Despite the good preservation of the stone, not one editor has so far correctly reported the final line. Mommsen did not see the stone and was only able to report the garbled reading of Alessi, in Giornale del gab. lett. dell' Acc. Gioenia 3 (1834), p.18 (non vidi). Ferrua and Manganaro both mistakenly reported the presence of a final C on the line; Bivona mistakenly reported the final name as only HER on the stone; Manganaro argued that the final M of Herm(es) in fact is MA in ligature and so Herma, but the supposed trace of a possible cross-bar on the second half of the M, to give A, appears to be part of adjacent damage on the stone, besides the implausibility of the female name in context, and the original reading of Herm(es) seems far preferable.
